content:
** Unknown if Homer was one person or multiple May have inserted himself into his works as a type of self-portrait The Illiad Exists within 900 year space- most likely originally transcribed from oral history Transcribed approx 1 century after conception 16,000 lines long and composed 10 years before war between the Greeks and the Trojans. The Trojan war This war took place approx 4 years before the piece was written We start in the middle of the war Talks of the flood-almost like in Gilgamesh Couple spared in the flood and tasked with repopulating the earth through throwing stones (the bones of the earth) Troy is the western coast of Turkey Several layers have been excavated in this region discovering cities (9) Some evidence of war in this region from excavations The Hittite kingdom was located near the East of the Troy - can easily make cultural references/connection The Trojan war is started by the Judgement of Paris in which he chooses Aphrodite for love over two other Goddesses, Athena and Hera/ Paris seduced Helen, wife of Spartan Lord Menelaus. Menelaus seeks the aid of his brother Agamemnon. The content of the poem centers around Achilles, the greatest warrior of Agamemnon’s forces Angered the god Apollo by kidnapping Chryseis- the daughter of the high priest Chryses Forced to give up this woman, Agamemnon takes Achilles concubine Briseis in return, angering Achilles and provoking the warrior to “sit out” the war. He will return Achilles is accidentally killed Tension in this poem is that of the immortality of the gods and the mortality of the humans Achilles must reconcile himself to his own mortality Gods have to recognize just how much they’ve become- involved and immersed in human activity Gilgamesh and the Iliad have many similarities The Trojan horse The Odyssey Multiple narratorial perspectives, Odysseus tells his story in the first person in the middle. Dactylic Hexameter is a line of poetry with six metrical feet (one strong stress and two weak stresses) Major spaces: The main hall of Odyseeus kingdom Coming of age, growing old The collateral of war Wit and intellect over sheer fore Arbitrary acts of the gods and the powerlessness of humanity The Odyssey# Books 1-8# We start with summary of the whole: “He came to see / many people’s cities, where he learned their customs, / while on the sea his spirit suffered many torments” (1.3-5)] Almost like a muse We begin with an assembly of the gods, with Zeus and Athena speaking (Athena loves Odysseus for his cunning and his battle prowess) Zeus: “How could I forget godlike Odysseus, / pre-eminent among all mortal men for his intelligence and offerings / to the mortal gods” (1.66-68) Some linkage to the Illiad The gods will send Hermes, the messenger god, to Calypso, who holds Odysseus on her island (he’s been there seven years) Athena goes to Ithaca, to Odysseus’ palace where his son, Telemachus must entertain suitors to his mother (vying for her hand in marriage with Odysseus gone so long and presumed dead). Note the **hospitality **of Telemachus to the disguised goddess; hospitality is a significant theme in this text, so obsessed with feasting! Notice the contrast between Telemachus and the suitors. Notice too how the bard Phemius performs a song of Achaeans returning from Troy (but Penelope stops him from singing that “painful song” (1.276). Odysseus is a poor young man Hospitality is a central theme of the text and the culture as a whole The idea that when aiding a stranger, you actually might be aiding a god or gods in disguise- you may be rewarded for your actions- so be kind Telemachus is angry with all the suitors- Athena advises Telemachus to sail off and seek the word of his father (King Nestor in Pylos and the to Menelaus in Sparta) ““If you think it’s better and would prefer / that one man’s livelihood should be consumed / without paying anything, I’ll call on / the immortal gods to see if mighty Zeus / will bring about an act of retribution” (1.319-23)” “Telemachus spoke, then threw the scepter on the ground / and burst out crying” (2.52-53). Wily Penelope quote about the suitors- sounds similar to her husband Odysseus “you [suitors] must wait, / although you are keen for me to marry, / till I complete this cloak—for if I don’t, / my weaving would be wasted and in vain” (2.74-77) [but, after four years, she is betrayed by one of her women] Female characters are shown throughout the text weaving (including Athena)- a metaphor for how the narrative of the story is being shaped and spun over time Betrayed by a female servant who thus ends her resistance to the suitors (cant stop them) Athena roams Ithaca in disguise as Telemachus to recruit sailors for him in order to ensure that he is able to depart in a swift manner In Book 3 (omitted from your books), Telemachus will sail to Peleponnese (southern Greece) and journey by land to the city of Pylos where he will be entertained by his father’s old comrade, King Nestor. The King offers his own account of the battles at Troy and his return home to Pylos. The King will send Telemachus on, further, to Sparta to see Menelaus. Nestor’s son, Pisistratus (same name as later Athenian ruler) will accompany Telemachus. Telemachus compares the Hall of Menelaus to Zeus’s kingdom- and is corrected by Minnelaus: “No man alive could rival Zeus, dear boys, / with his everlasting palace and possessions” (4.87-88). Meleanus grieves for Odyseus and recognizes Telemachus by his resemblance to his father Helen’s and Menelaus’ account of Odysseus sneaking into Troy as a beggar and, then, the Trojan Horse: “We heard you [Helen] call. / Two of us—Diomedes and myself—were eager to get up and charge outside / or else to answer back from where we sat, in side the horse. But Odysseus stopped us—/we wished to speak, but he held us in check” (4.86-90) Helen admits that she might have been drugged in Troy We are reminded of the characters own mortality Athena appeals to the gods to aid Odysseus, who is still trapped on the island with Calypso and has been for 7 years. Athena describes the ambush that is being set for Telemachus. Hermes goes to Calypso to tell her that Odysseus must leave the island. Further establishes the theme of mortality vs immortality Odysseus sits regularly by the sea “his eyes always full of tears / because he was squandering his sweet life, mourning / for his return” (5.100-103).
Odysseus is Desperate for immortality
Monsters stand at the threshold of becoming “Monsters ask us how we perceive our world and “how we have misrepresented what we have attempted to place.” Odysseus starts to embrace his humanity and mortality Odysseus has to leave the island and must build his own boat in order to leave it Reminded of what it means to be a mortal in the realm of the gods However, Poseidon (Sea god) makes his journey difficult and Odysseus ends up washed up on the the shores of Paheacia “Here’s trouble! In this country I have reached, what are the people like? Are they violent and untamed, without a sense of justice? Or are they kind to strangers? In their minds do they fear the gods?” Book 7: Odysseus appears with the queen of the Phoenicians, Arete, and her husband King Alcinous Oyssedeus asks for kindness from the queen Another example of hospitality and sanctuary Alcinous: “If he’s a deathless one come down from heaven, / then gods are planning something different. / So far they’ve always shown themselves to us / in their true form” (7.78-80) They think that Ossyedus may have been sent from the gods However, Odysseus explains that he is mortal and not a god “I’m like mortal men. Indeed, I could recount a longer story, all those hardships I have had to suffer.” (To Alcinous) “After they enjoyed their heart’s fill of food and drink, the minstrel Demodocus, inspired by the Muse, sang about the glorious deeds of warriors, that story, whose fame had climbed to spacious heaven, about Odysseus and Achilles, son of Peleus, when, at a lavish feat in honor of the gods, they fought each other in ferocious argument” (8.34-40) Get a glimpse into the Greek Culture Another feast occurs between Aphrodite and and Ares which Hephaestus (Vulcan) learns about and is embarrassed and angry ““Nasty deeds don’t pay. / The slow one overtakes the swift just as / Hephaestus, slow as he is, has caught Ares, / although of all gods who hold Olympus / he’s the fastest one there is. Yes, he’s lame, / but he’s a crafty one” (124-29). The tortoise and the hare type of situation “He sang about the various ways those warriors / laid waste that lofty town [Troy] and how Odysseus, / like Ares, god of war, and noble Menelaus / went to the home of Deiphobus [Trojan prince], where, he said / Odysseus battled in the most horrendous fight, / from which he then emerged at last victorious” (8.249-54) Omitted text from my edition: “That was the song the famous harper sang / but great Odysseus melted into tears, / … / as a woman weeps, her arms flung around her darling husband, / a man who fell in battle, fighting for town and townsman, / trying to beat the day of doom from home and children. / Seeing the man go down, dying, gasping for breath, / she clings for dear life, screams and shrills—/ but the victors, just behind her, / digging spear-butts into her back and shoulders, / drag her off in bondage, yoked to hard labor, pain, / and the most heartbreaking torment wastes her cheeks. / So from Odysseus’ eyes ran tears of heartbreak now.” Oyssedus ponders his actions, killing,etc. Book 9: Odysseus becomes the bard and the storyteller “now I’ll speak / of the unhappy journey back which Zeus / arranged for me when I returned from war” (9.29-30) The Cicones (failure of his men to find moderation in their savagery and drunkenness) After leaving Troy, Odysseus and her men aim to get more spoils and more goods and material wealth in order to take home Heading to Immarus Plundering artifacts from countries Countries fight against Odysseus Crew ends up off course and in the land of the Lotus-eaters They manage to get away unharmed Questions: What does it mean to remember? What does it mean to forget? What is necessary to keep/lose? Questions of history and its making History has many flows Crew then ends up in the land of the Cyclopes- Takes 12 companions to seek hospitality from the locals who lead them to a cave where Polyphemus live “No man” Tricks the other cyclops “From the cave mighty Polyphemus roared: ‘Nobody is killing me, my friends, / by treachery, not using any force”’ (9.403-4). “He stretched out his arms, / attempting to catch anyone who tried / to escape there with the sheep” (9.415-17).” Polyphemus kills 2 of the men and eats them In order to escape, they must have Polyphemus open the door to the cave so that they can escape Get him drunk- They blind him with a stick and he is therefore unable to find Odysseus Odysseus abuses verbally the Polyphemus (Poseidon’s son)- makes Poseidon hate Odysseus The cyclops; “They don’t grow / any plants by hand or plough the earth, / but put their trust in the immortal gods, / and though they never sow or work the land, / still every kind of crop springs up for them” (9.92-96). “Each one of them / sets out laws for his own wives and children, / and they shun all dealings with each other” (9.101-103). “He avoided others / and lived alone, away from all the rest, / a law unto himself, a monster, made to be a thing of wonder, not like a man, / who survives by eating bread, no, more like / a soaring wooded mountain standing there / to view in isolation from the rest” (9.145-51 ). “l told the rest of my trustworthy crew / to stay there beside the ship and guard it, / while I selected twelve of my best men / and went off to explore. I took with me / a goatskin full of dark sweet wine” (9.152-55). “l was keen / to see the man in person and find out / if he would show me hospitality (9.180-82). “We’re here / as suppliants to you, and Zeus protects / all suppliants and strangers—as god of guests, / he cares for all respected visitors” (9.218-21 ). Another example of the theme of hospitality Men are brash to assume that the host will agree to their indulgence Odysseus escaped through hanging onto the bottom of the sheep Another instance of Odysseus being mortal, cannot compete with the might of a god such as Poseidon Odysseus travels to Aeolia Aeolus gives Odysseus a bag of ox hide Unknown why he did this In reality this is the “bag of winds” They can see Ithaca- Odysseus falls asleep The others on the boat open the sack in order to see what is in it (they seemed to believe that it was treasure) The winds and seas push the boat back to Aeolia King is furious- no lenience “Of all living mortals, you are the worst— so you must leave this island with all speed. It would violate all sense of what is right if I helped out or guided on his way a man the blessed gods must hate. So leave. You’re here because the deathless gods despise you.” “Once they heard his [Antiphates] call, / the mighty Laestrygonians poured out, / thronging in countless numbers from all sides—/ not like men at all, but Giants” (131-34). They encounter man-eating giants called Laestrygonians Trapped the 12 ships- only Odysseus ship escaped They then encounter Circe and her island-turns a party of men into pigs- one escapes to warn the others Hermes gives him the antidote to Circe’s powers- makes Circe vow not to plot or take revenge against his crew. Chapter 1# Sound beings with the vibration of an object Sound transmitted by a medium Music is part of the world of sound Pitch: Highness or Lowness of Sound# Pitch → Highness or lowness of a sound Sound that has a definite pitch is called a tone Has a specific frequency Vibrations of a tone are regular and reach the ear at regular intervals Tones will sound different with different pitches Interval of an octave - interval between first and last tones of the scale Octave has seven different pitched before arriving at the high note which duplicates the first one 7 tones on the keyboard Added 12 tones are duplicated in higher and lower octaves Distance is known as the pitch range Most music is based on definite pitches Dynamics# Dynamics → Degrees of loudness or softness are known as Loudness or softness affects the type of the sound Italian terms indicate dynamics Ways to indicate dynamical changes Not super precise Tone has a dynamic level - in relation to other tones around the instrument or vocal Tone Color# Tone color or Timbre descriptions Bright Dark Brilliant Mellow Rich Even though instruments might sound the same, the sound that the instrument creates will likely vary Chapter 2# Voices# Singing demands a greater control of pitch and volume Range of singers voice depends on training and physical makeup Professionals usually have a vocal range of about 2 octaves Musical Instruments# Any mechanism other than a voice that produce musical sounds
Most instruments have a wider range than voices
6 categories of music
Woodwind Brass String Percussion Keyboard Electronic Instruments have different sizes for different sound ranges
Instruments are popular based off of the barrier to entry to the general public
Compositions can be written for more than one person and to large orchestras
A diagram of an orchestra and the different sections of the orchestra
String Instruments# Instruments Violin Viola Cello Double Bass All instruments are similar in setup and are made in the same manner Strings have greatest versatility and expressive range Pizzicato → Plucked string Double Stop → Drawing the bow across two strings Can also be with 3 or 4 strings Vibrato → Throbbing expressive tone while vibrating the string using the fingerboard Mute → Veil or muffle the tone Tremolo → Very high-pitched tones Woodwind Instruments# Produce vibrations of air within a tube Traditionally made of wood All have holes along the length of the instrument that are opened or closed by a key mechanism - similar to how the sound of the recorder changes when you cover the holes Woodwinds are very different from each other in terms of tone color Reed- piece of cane Flute- blow over the edge of a mouth hole Brass Instruments# Main instruments Trumpet French Horn Trombone Tuba Mouthpiece - cup shaped funnel that you blow into to play Tube is flared to form a bell at the end of the instruments Mute alters the tone color - can be inserted into the bell Very powerful- used for climaxes in pieces or for powerful. Also given solo passages Percussion# Struck with hand, sticks or hammers or shaken or rubbed Vibrations of percussion instruments are caused by stretched membranes for certain instruments or by plates, bars ,etc. Percussion instruments have been used to emphasize rhythm, build suspense, etc. Oft used by Jazz Musicians Keyboard instruments# Instruments Piano Invented around 1700- perfected by the 1850’s Sound produced by strings and hammers The more that you hit the string, the louder it will be Pedals to sustain the tone, veil tone, sustains some tones, not others Harpsichord 1775- replaced by pianos Harpsichord Organ Accordion Pipe Organ Often used for religious ceremonies Accordian Most used in folk setting Electronic Instruments# Produce or amplify sound via electronic means Invented around 1904 Significant impact on music since 1950 Types Electric piano Electric Organ Electric Guitars Synthesizers Generate, modify, and control sound Can be played via a keyboard 1960’s-70’s smaller, less expensive keyboards developed Allow for the manipulation of sounds MIDI, synthesizers work like a Piano Tape Studio Main tool in the 1950’s Les Paul,etc Including recorded sounds Manipulated sounds Sampling enables composers to hear what their music sounds like using digital technology Digital Audio Workstations → DAWs Chapter 3# Rhythm# Recurring pattern of tension and release Refers to the ordered durations of sounds and silence Beat# Regular, recurrent pulsation Units of time in which all tones are measured Combination of different durations of tones creates the rhythm Meter# All of this is part of meter Some beats feel stronger or more stressed than others Meter → The organization of beats into regular groups Measure or Bar → A group containing a fixed number of number of beats Downbeat → The first or stressed beat of the measure Quadruple meter → 4 beats to the measure, the downbeat is the strongest Jazz and Rock are usually quadruple meter Sextuple Meter→ 6 rather quick beats to the measure Accent and Syncopation# Individual notes are stressed - how they get special emphasis Accent - note is emphasized by being played louder than the notes around it Syncopation → Accented note comes where there one is not expected When an offbeat note is accented Tempo# Tempo is the speed of the beat Fast → associated of energy, drive and excitement Slow → Solemn, lyrical and calm mood Tempo indication is usually given at beginning of a piece in Italian Accelerando - quickening of the tempo Ritardando - becoming slower Chapter 4- Notating Pitch# Horizontal lines on a staff are called ledger lines Seven pitches/tones are: A, B, C, D, E, F, G Repeated over to represent the same tones in higher and lower octaves Other 5 tones of the octave correspond to the black keys of the piano Indicated by sharp sign or a flat sign Natural sign cancel a previous sharp or flat sign Clef is placed at the beginning of the staff Treble clef- used for high ranges Bass clef- used for low ranges Notating Rhythm# Nation does not indicate the exact duration of tones, it shows how long oen tone lasts in relation to others in the same piece Depends on how the note is written- with stems or flags To lengthen a notes, we can make it a dotted note - increases the duration of the note by a half Tue also lengthens the duration of the note- connected by a tie Rhythmic variety - triplet, etc. Notating silence# Notating Meter# Time signature/ meter signature shows the meter of a peice
Appears at the beginning of the staff at the start of a piece
$$ \frac{2}{4} \text{-2 beats to the measure and a quarter note gets 1 beat. The most common meter is} \frac{3}{4}. \text{Quadruple meter is} \frac{4}{4} $$
Chapter 5# Melody# Melody → Series of single tones that add up to add up to a recognizable whole Has direction, shape and continuity Conveys tension and release, expectation and arrival Melodic curve or line Climax - The highest note of a melody Legato → Sung or played in a smooth or connected setup Staccato → May be performed in a short or detached matter Letters commonly used for discussing the segments of the peices lowercase for shorter sections (a,b,etc) Uppercase letters for longer sections (A,B,etc) Melody and Words# Melody expresses the meaning and emotion of the words Melody can evoke feeling in the listeners Chapter 6- Harmony# Harmony refers to the way chords are constructed and how they follow each other Consonance and Dissonance# Consonance → A tone combination that is stable Dissonance → A tone combination that is unstable Tension demands an onward motion to a stable Resolution → Dissonance has its resolution when it moves to a consonance Consonance and dissonance can exist in varying degrees Some or more or less stable than other The Triad# Triad → Most basic chord Harmony- simultaneous tones in music that add support and richness to melody Tonic chord → The main chord of the piece Subdominant chord - the triad based on the fourth note of the scale Dominant chord- built on the fifth note Cadence - means both the resting point at the end of the melodic phrase Broken Chords (Arpeggios)# Broken Chord or Arpeggio - Individual tones of a chord are sounded one after another Chapter 7- Key# Key involves not only a central tone but also a central scale or chord Scale is the basic pitches of a piece of music arranged from low to high The Major Key# The major scale has two kinds of intervals: Half-steps and whole-steps Half-step is the smallest interval traditionally used in western music Whole step is twice as large as the half step The Minor Scale# Consists of seven different tones and an eighth tone that duplicates the first an octave higher Minor scale can begin on any of the twelve tones in an octave Thus, there are 12 minor scales Major and Minor keys# When a piece is based off of a major scale → Major Key When a piece of music is based off of a minor scale → Minor Key To indicate the key of a music - composer uses a key signature The Chromatic Scale# Twelve tones of the octave form the chromatic scale Tones of the chromatic scale same distance apart, unlike major and minor scales Tones are one half-step apart Chromatic scale does not define a key Contribute to a sense of motion and tension Modulation- Change of key# Short pieces of music - single key from beginning to end Longer pieces of music, variety or contrast created by using more than one key Modulation → Shifting from one key to another within the piece Tonic Key# No matter the amount that a piece has been changed, there is usually only one home note Modulation is moving away from the home key, but then eventually returning to the home key Chapter 8- Musical Texture# Musical texture - refers to how many different layers of sound are heard at a time Described as: Dense Thin Thick Heavy Light Monophonic Texture# Monophonic → Having one sound Singing alone Single line with the same pitch in unison makes a stronger sound than singing alone Polyphonic Texture# Polyphonic → Having many sounds Each line of the piece enriches the other Counterpoint → Combining several melodic lines into a whole Round → song in which the same melody is sung or played at slightly different times Homophonic Texture# Homophonic → One main melody accompanied by chords Chords are subordinate to the melody Chapter 9- Musical forms# Form → organization of musical elements in time Techniques that Create Musical Form# Repetition → Creates a sense of unity Contrast → Provides variety Variation → keeps some elements of musical thought while changing others - gives a work unity and variety at the same time Repetition# Appeals to the pleasure we get in recognizing and remembering something Passage of time influences our reaction to repetition Contrast# Forward motion, conflict and change of mood Variation# Some ideas will be retained while others are changed Melody might be restated with a different accompaniment Types of Musical form# ABA Form# Contrast between A and B and then return to AB (Binary form)# Composition made up of two section is in two part form AABB Chapter 10- Musical Style# Style - refers to a characteristic was of using melody, rhythm, tone color The was these elements are combined can result in a total sound that’s unique Musical styles can change from one era to the next History of western art can be divided into the periods: Middle Ages (450-1450) Renaissance (1450-1600) Baroque (1600-1750) Classical (1750-1820) Romantic (1820-1900) Twentieth century to 1945 1945 to the present

Romanticism in Music# About 1820-1900 Franz Schubert, Robert Schumann, Clara Wieck Schumann, Hendel, Dvorak, etc. Continued to use the musical forms of the classical era Emotional intensity was already present in Classical work Romantic music usually have a greater range of tone color, dynamics and pitch Harmonic vocabulary is broader More emphasis on colorful, unstable chords Linked more closely to other arts- literature Characteristics of Romantic Music# Individuality of Style# Expression of the individual and the individuality of self Tchaikovsky, Chopin, Schumann were some of the pioneers of this style Expressive Aims and Subjects# Flamboyance and intimacy, unpredictability, melancholy, rapture and longing Glorification of Romantic love Fantastic and Diabolical Dream of a Witches’ sabbath All aspects of Nature attracted Romantic musicians Subjects drawn from the Middle Ages and Shakespeare Nationalism and Exoticism# Composers create music that express a National Identity Exoticism → Composers drawing on colorful materials from foreign lands Program Music# Program Music → Instrumental music associated with a story, poem or idea Can represent the emotions, characters, and events of a particular story. can evoke the sounds and motion of nature Romeo and Juliet - Tchaikovsky Music matches the mood of the scene Expressive Tone Color# Rich and sensuous sound Timbre is extremely important Romantic orchestra is larger and more varied in tone color than the classical orchestra 100 ish people 20-60 in classical Brass, Woodwind, Percussion take on a more active role Brass Trombones, Trumpets, etc Woodwind Bass Clarinet English horn Piccolo Composers want to blend and combine tone colors Piano vastly improved during the 1820s and 1830s Piano tone became more “singing” Range extended Pianist could produce more sound due to a larger instrument Damper pedal allowed for blend of tones from all registers of the piano Colorful Harmony# Explored new chords/existing chords Emphasized greater emotional intensity, rich, colorful and complex harmonies Chromatic harmony → Uses chords containing tones not found in the prevailing major or minor scale Chromatic scale Add color and motion to romantic music Expanded Range of Dynamics, Pitch, Tempo# Sharp contrasts between dynamics ffff, pppp, etc. More expressiveness- use crescendos, etc Often accompanied by changes in pace Form: Miniature and Monumental# Thematic transformation - change the melody as it returns later in a piece by changing dynamics, etc. Different movements of a romantic work can be linked together through transitional passages Romantic Composers and Their Public# Composers role in society changed greatly during the time of Beethoven Part of the musicians job had been the composition of works for a specific occasion and audience Bach wrote cantatas for weekly church services One of the first musicians to work freelance This image of Beethoven inspired romantic writers Romantic composers were interested in pleasing those around them and being judged fairly by posterity Free artists by necessity rather than choice Many aristocrats could not afford to have court musicians Romantic composers wrote primarily for a middle class audience Citizens expanded dramatically and people want to hear music First half of the nineteenth century witnessed the founding of music conservatories throughout Europe Captured by virtuosity Private music making also increased during the romantic era Piano becomes a fixture in middle class homes Romantic composers came from the social class that was their main audience It was difficult for children to make a living through music Most composers were forced to work at many areas at work Sonata Form# Sonata form → Refers to the form of a single movement Exposition → Themes are presented
Development → Themes are treated in new ways
Recapitulation → Themes return
💡Exposition First theme in tonic (home) key Bridge containing modulation from home key to new key Second theme in new key Closing section in key of second theme Development New treatment of themes; modulations to different keys Recapitulation First theme in tonic key Bridge Second theme in tonic key Closing section in tonic key Coda In tonic key
Exposition# Strong conflict between the tonic key and the new key Bridge or Transition → leads to the second theme Usually a repeat sign at the end of the exposition in order to indicate if it should be played again Development# Most dramatic section of the movement Rapid modulations and the harmonic tension is heightened Themes are broken into fragments or motives Recapitulation# Brings resolution as we hear the first theme in the tonic key Coda# Powerful feeling of conclusion is attained by following recapitulation with another section Coda rounds off a movement by repeating themes or developing them further Always ends in the tonic key Sonata form is exceptionally flexible and subject to endless variation Viewed as a set of principles that serve to shape and unify contrasts of theme and key Symphony No 40# Controlled agitation in opening Persistence of this rhythmic pattern gives the music a sense of urgency Melody is balanced and symmetrical [msedge_TJoiOBqOh1.png](<https://prod-files-secure.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/8147ef02-8109-4add-a936-9c2f026e2ec7/edafeb9c-80df-45b1-9a9c-c95aa23ae7b3/msedge_TJoiOBqOh1.png>) Theme and Variation# Theme and Variations was widely used in the classical period
A basic musical idea (theme) is repeated over and over and is changed each time A

Each variation is unique
Usually same length as the theme Changes of melody, rhythm, harmony, accompaniment, dynamics, or tone color Core melody may appear in the bass or it may be repeated in a diff key Composer might invent an original melody or use someone else
Minuet and Trio# Often used as the third movement in classical symphonies
First appeared at Court of Louis XIV
Movement of a symphony is written for listening, not dancing
It is in triple meter 3/4 ABA form Minuet- A
Trio - B
Minuet- A
Often contains woodwind solos
Minuet is structurally the simplest movement of a symphony or quartet
In many of Beethoven’s works, the third movement is not a minuet but related form called a scherzo Rondo# Rondo → Tuneful main theme (A) that returns several times-alternation with other themes AVACA ABACABA Main theme is usually stated in the tonic key, its return is all the more welcome Rondo form is often combined with elements of sonata form to produce a sonata-rondo Contains a development section like that in sonata form is outlined ABA-development-ABA The Classical Symphony# Greatest contribution of the classical period to orchestral music is symphonies
Haydn = 1-4 symphonies Mozart = 40+ Beethoven = 9 Symphony → Extended, ambitious composition typically lasting between twenty and 45 min. Uses the expanded range of tone color and dynamics of the classical orchestra
Usually consists of four movements that evoke a wide range of emotions through contrasts of tempo and mood Vigorous- Dramatic fast movement
Usually the most dramatic movement Sonata form A lyrical slow movement
Most likely to find broad, songlike melodies here Sonata form: ABA Dancelike movement (minuet or scherzo)
For Haydn and Mozart is generally a minuet and trio which may be in a moderate or fairly quick tempo Varies from courtly dance to a peasant romp or vigorous piece that is not very dancelike Beethoven likes fast, energetic scherzos A brilliant or heroic fast movement
Concluding movement of a symphony by Haydn or Mozart is fast, lively and brilliant but somewhat lighter in mood than the opening statement In most of the classical symphonies each movement is a self contained composition with its own set of themes
A theme in one movement will only rarely reappear in a later movement
Importance of the symphony lasted throughout the twentieth century and into the twenty-first

Chapter 5# The Art song (lied)# Art sing is a composition for solo voice and piano Accompaniment is a integral part of the composers concept Original meant to be sung at home, not at concert halls Poetry and music are fused in the art song - flourished with increasing amount of romantic poetry Song composers would interpret or translate a poem into musical form Song Forms# Strophic form makes a song easy to remember and is used in almost all folk songs Repeats the same music in each stanza Through composed forms writes new music for each stanza Used to reflect poems changing moods The Song Cycle# Romantic songs are usually grouped in a set or, song cycle Sometimes unified by a story line that runs through poems or by musical ideas that link the songs Franz Schubert# 1797-1828 Earliest master of the Romantic art song Never held an official position- made his income entirely through composition Schubert was born in Vienna, son of a schoolmaster Composed a large number of works in his late teenage years Wrote Gretchen am Spindale and The Erlking Composed close to 200 works per year Most of his works were designed to be performed for the middle class Did not mingle with the aristocracy Died in 1828 at the age of 31 Schubert’s Music# Schubert composed over 600 works The melodies of his songs have a larger variety of moods and types. Some folklike tunes to complex lines that suggest impassioned speech Schubert’s harmonies and dissonances provide some poetic moments in music Spirit of song permeates Schubert’s music too Symphonies and chamber works have longer lyrical melodies Most of his famous Trout Quintet in A minor Most of the symphonies and chamber works have long, lyrical melodies which are sometimes comparable in power and intensity to those his idol Erlking is a great example of musical romanticism Piano part builds the excitement of the work Also the piano parts unifies the episodes of the song and suggests the Gifted individuals Became president of the New Academy of Music Liszt’s Music# Created the Symphonic poem- a one movement orchestral composition based to some extent on literary or pectoral ideas Felix Mendelson# Romantic whose music was rooted in classical tradition Born in Hamburg Germany Young prodigy Conducted Bach’s St Matthews Passion in its first performance since Bachs death Rekindled interest in Bachs music Earned him an international reputation Often visited and played for Queen Victoria Personal life more conventional than most romantic composers Fanny Mendelssohn Hensel# Older sister of Felix Melssohn
Since the 1980s, her works have become more and more performed
At thirteen, in honor of her father’s birthday, Fanny played from memory all the twenty-four Preludes from Bach’s The Well-Tempered Clavier, and at fourteen, composed songs and piano pieces. However, her father limited Fanny’s musical ambitions by saying that as an upper-class young woman she could never aspire to be a professional musician like her brother Felix: “Music will perhaps be his profession, whilst for you it can only be an ornament, never the root of your being and doing.” Even her beloved brother Felix agreed with their father and discouraged Fanny from publishing her compositions. In 1826, two of her songs were published together with four songs by Felix under his name. Years later Felix visited Queen Victoria at Buckingham Palace and accompanied her as she sang a song she thought was by him. After the Queen praised the song, Felix admitted to her that it was composed by his sister. When she was twenty-three, Fanny married Wilhelm Hensel, painter at the court in Berlin, who encouraged her musical activities. The couple’s only child was named Sebastian Ludwig Felix Hensel after Fanny’s favorite composers, Johann Sebastian Bach, Ludwig van Beethoven, and Felix Mendelssohn. In 1831, Fanny became music director and performer at Sunday concerts in the Mendelssohn family mansion, reviving the musicales her parents had hosted years before. Fanny’s concerts were attended by up to 200 invited guests from Berlin’s elite. The works heard included compositions ranging from Bach to Chopin, and guest performers included such famous virtuosos as Clara Schumann and Franz Liszt. In 1846, persuaded by praise from musicians, Fanny wrote in her diary, “I have made up my mind to publish my things.” To Felix she wrote: “I am as afraid of you my brother at age 40 as I was of Father at age 14…1 hope I won’t disgrace all of you through my publishing.” Felix replied giving Fanny his “professional blessing on your decision to join our guild.” Several of her works finally appeared in print under her name, but less than a year later, in 1847 at age forty-one, Fanny died of a stroke.
